message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of high-grade fever and ecchymosis along with the lab investigations suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (Tdt) is a marker for immature B cells, which is consistent with the suspected diagnosis. MHC II is expressed on antigen-presenting cells, CD56 on natural killer cells, and CD16 on natural killer cells and macrophages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab investigations suggest leukemia, and the given options are related to cell markers. CD19 and Tdt are present in immature B cells, which suggest the neoplastic proliferation of these cells. The other options are related to natural killer cells and mature B cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory findings suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. Detection of CD19 and Tdt (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase) would help confirm the diagnosis, as these markers are typically expressed on immature B cells. MHC II is a marker for antigen-presenting cells, CD56 is a marker for natural killer cells, and CD16 is a marker for natural killer cells and some subsets of T cells, but none of these would be specific for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab results and symptoms suggest that the boy may have acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is characterized by the neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. The marker CD19 is commonly used to identify B cells, and Tdt is an enzyme that is expressed by immature lymphoid cells, so detection of CD19 and Tdt would help confirm the diagnosis of ALL. MHC II is a marker for antigen-presenting cells, CD56 is a marker for natural killer cells, and CD16 is a marker for natural killer cells and some subtypes of T cells, so they are not specific to B cell neoplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of symptoms suggests acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is characterized by the neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. CD19 and Tdt are both markers found on the surface of B cells and are commonly used in the diagnosis of ALL. MHC II is found on antigen-presenting cells, while CD56 and CD16 are found on natural killer cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab results indicate the possibility of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is characterized by neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. CD19 and Tdt are both markers commonly expressed on B-cell precursors and are useful in confirming the diagnosis of ALL. MHC II is involved in antigen presentation, CD56 is a marker for natural killer cells, and CD16 is a marker for natural killer cells and neutrophils and are not specific in diagnosing acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is a neoplastic proliferation of immature B or T lymphocytes. CD19 and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (Tdt) are markers that confirm the diagnosis of ALL. MHC II is not specific to lymphoblastic leukemia, while CD56 and CD16 are markers for natural killer (NK) cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is a neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. CD19 and Tdt are markers of B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia and would help confirm the suspected diagnosis. MHC II is not specific to any type of leukemia, and CD56 and CD16 are markers for natural killer cells and myeloid cells, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and lab results are consistent with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which arises from neoplastic proliferation of immature B cells. CD19 and Tdt are commonly expressed on ALL cells and detection of these markers would confirm the diagnosis. MHC II is expressed on antigen-presenting cells, CD56 is expressed on natural killer cells, and CD16 is expressed on natural killer cells and macrophages, but none of these markers are specific to ALL.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab results suggest acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which is a neoplastic proliferation of immature B or T cells. CD19 and Tdt are markers commonly expressed on the surface of B cells, with Tdt being expressed on the surface of immature B cells. Detecting these markers would confirm the suspected diagnosis of ALL. MHC II is a major histocompatibility complex marker, CD56 is a natural killer cell marker, and CD16 is a Fc receptor expressed on the surface of cytotoxic cells, none of which are specific markers for ALL.
